instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power
threads.message: I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no power but orange light on magsafe. Tracked it down to a short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> under <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR>. When I removed the component, the short is still present and there seems to be soon peeling of the upper layers on the board. See attached picture. Is it salvageable ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power
threads.message: You can try and dig it out and rewire it. But also check the resistance to GND on L7630. The 12.56V probably got to the 1.05V bus.
